description: After emergency Council consultation, Sven Halek chooses to suppress Halden’s reset broadcast. He instead authorizes information channels to quietly coordinate with grassroots groups about the upcoming reemergence of disappeared citizens, preparing city officials for public shock.

Hundreds of disappeared citizens return throughout Stenograd. Many are traumatized, with muted affect and similar accounts of isolation and psychological 'testing.' Their synchronized behavior raises suspicions of secret conditioning during absence.

Neighborhood forums and city assemblies erupt with debate over the returnees. Allegations of hidden programming surface, and some neighborhoods demand investigation, while others push for full support and transparency.

The Council and its analysts argue over whether the returnees should help shape new BCI reform. Fears grow about lingering influences from hidden protocols, paralyzing consensus and adding urgency to citywide calls for justice.

A citywide referendum is held to decide policies on the reintegration of returnees and to place new limits on BCI power. The mass return sparks a reckoning with the human cost of automated governance.
